Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer made a perverse decision regarding changes in country conditions
Application_Facts: Applicant denied refugee status may present new evidence in PRRA; officer must assess risk based on credible evidence and changing country conditions
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to lack of new evidence showing worsened conditions
Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review allowed; matter referred for redetermination
Defendant_Behavior: PRRA officer failed to compare 2002 conditions with 2004-2005 reports documenting significant human rights abuses
Assessment_Factor: Credible evidence of changing country conditions
Credibility_Assessment: Officer did not adequately assess credibility of new evidence on country conditions
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports from 2004-2005 showing human rights abuses in Egypt
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of IRPA allowing PRRA submissions based on new evidence
Application_Basis: New evidence of deteriorating human rights situation in Egypt
Evidence_Assessed: Lack of comparison between 2002 and 2004â€“2005 country condition reports
Relief_Sought: Redetermination of PRRA by a different panel
Governing_Rule: Under IRPA, applicants may submit new evidence in PRRA; officers must consider changes in country conditions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider relevant country condition reports from 2004-2005
Outcome: Decision found patently unreasonable; case remitted for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Risk of return to Egypt under worsened human rights conditions
Cause_Description: Applicant claimed persecution in Egypt and sought judicial review after PRRA rejection
Evidence_Handling: New evidence on country conditions not properly analyzed or compared
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions related to fair assessment of PRRA applications based on updated country conditions
Evidence_Issues: Omission of key country reports in assessing change in circumstances
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer did not adequately assess new evidence of worsening conditions in Egypt
Decision_Rationale: Officer's failure to compare time periods rendered decision patently unreasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to incorporate and analyze post-2002 country condition reports
